properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall accumulations reaching 15 to 20 centimetres are expected from Monday afternoon through Tuesday evening. In addition, moderate to strong easterly winds may occasionally reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:41:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T20:42:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2156877234.2019

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon and tonight. Freezing rain has changed over to snow this afternoon. Bands of heavy snow will affect the area this afternoon through early Tuesday morning. Visibilities will be significantly reduced under the heaviest bands of snow. Total snowfall accumulations near 10 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Travel is likely to be affected across the area. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:02:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T20:03:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2522748363.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall through tonight. Snow, heavy at times, along with blowing snow is expected through tonight. Additional amounts of 10 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Poor travel conditions are expected due to blowing and accumulating snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice storm ending this afternoon. The freezing rain will transition to flurries or showers this afternoon. Ice accretion or build-up of 10 to 15 mm is possible and widespread power outages are likely. Poor travel conditions can be expected this afternoon and improving early this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T03:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:45:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2686187991.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice pellets mixed with freezing rain will change to snow early this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds could affect travel on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locally higher amounts possible, especially over Prince County. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 70 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: All of Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tuesday afternoon into early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and could mix with or changeover to ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain before changing to rain near midnight then ending early Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 70 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact travel across the province on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:43:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:44:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0809408640.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and strong winds expected on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 2 to 5 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to possibly 90 km/h. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine Time span: Late Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday evening and persist into the overnight period and taper to shower or flurries early Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting to 80 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening and persist overnight before diminishing later Wednesday morning, reducing visibilities in blowing snow. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact travel on the islands later New Year's Eve or New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:43:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:44:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3217893672.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: most of Newfoundland. Time span: overnight Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop over southwestern Newfoundland Tuesday night and spread across the Island on Wednesday. This could result in poor driving conditions on New Year's Day. The snow will likely change to rain along the south coast and southern Avalon Peninsula. Precipitation will taper off Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:24:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:25:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1197679211.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets changing to rain along with strong winds expected for New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 2 cm over southwestern Nova Scotia to 10 cm in the north, possibly higher over the Cape Breton Highlands. Total rainfall: 5 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h. Locations: All of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow or rain is expected to develop Tuesday morning over southwestern Nova Scotia then spread to all regions of the province by Tuesday evening. Snow will mix with ice pellets and there continues to be a risk of freezing rain before the changeover to rain. Strong southeast winds gusting to 70 to possibly 80 km/h will develop Tuesday afternoon and evening then diminish overnight. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation and strong winds could impact travel in parts of the province on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:44:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:45:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3017937200.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected on New Year's Eve. Locations: central to northern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin in the southwest Tuesday morning and spread towards the northeast by Tuesday afternoon. Central and eastern parts of the province could see a period of pellets or freezing rain or a changeover to rain overnight on Wednesday before tapering off to flurries in the morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:41:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:42:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1617965614.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and risk of freezing rain expected. A significant mix of wintry precipitation is expected over much of Northern Ontario today, including snow, ice pellets and a risk of freezing rain. This wintry mix will change to all snow this afternoon. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected today. Poor travel conditions can be expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T02:15:36-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow for New Year's Day... A low pressure system will intensify over the Maritimes, bringing snow and strong winds over the North Shore beginning Tuesday evening into Wednesday evening. Snowfall amounts approaching 15 centimetres are possible. Visibilities could be significantly reduced in blowing snow, making travel difficult during this period of festivities. Please consider modifying non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:43:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T20:44:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2344166771.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow for the New Year... A low pressure system will intensify over the Maritimes on Wednesday, bringing 10 to 15 centimetres of snow over the northern shore and the Parc de la Gaspésie. Moderate to strong northwesterly winds will develop Wednesday afternoon and evening and will cause blowing snow over exposed areas. Accumulating snow and poor visibility will make driving conditions difficult in this period of festivities. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:42:22-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A storm tracking across the northern interior this evening will continue to bring heavy snow to Pine Pass and Williston. 5 to 9 cm of snow has fallen over the region. Additional 5 to 10 cm snowfall is expected tonight. Snow will taper off to a few flurries or rain showers early Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T16:28:39-00:00

properties.Summary:

Dense fog patches are also possible. Ice accumulations tonight may add another 2 to 5 mm of ice and additional power outages are possible. Poor travel conditions can be expected tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A storm will track across the central interior of British Columbia today, bringing heavy snow to McGregor and eastern sections of Prince George region. Snow will taper off and become mixed with rain this evening over Prince George but could last through Tuesday over McGregor. Strong southerly winds will bring local blowing snow this afternoon and early this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC. Light snow will begin this evening over West Kootenay and Kootenay Pass. Snow will intensify early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 30 cm. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. The heavy snow is expected to ease overnight Tuesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T14:56:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T22:57:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0476489264.2019

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 100 km/h by midnight with higher gusts possible overnight. Time span: Late evening on Tuesday to early morning on Wednesday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. More freezing rain across the regions expected tonight. Precipitation crossing Lake Ontario will move into the regions this evening and freezing rain or snow is possible. Dense fog patches are also possible. After midnight a transition to flurries or showers are expected. Additional power outages are possible. ### Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:09:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T22:43:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3382526852.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Gusty winds tonight. Gusty winds up to 65 kilometres per hour will continue over the regions through this evening and may cause further power outages due to the ice accumulation on trees and structures. The winds should gradually diminish overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:59:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T23:51:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2593322283.2019
Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County, Caledon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 110 km/h. Time span: overnight Tuesday night until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds will develop Tuesday night with gusts to 110 km/h by Wednesday morning. Winds will ease and shift to southwesterly Wednesday afternoon. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-31T11:14:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T19:15:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4266967779.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC. Light snow will begin this evening over West Kootenay and Kootenay Pass. Snow will intensify early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 30 cm. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. The heavy snow is expected to ease overnight Tuesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T14:56:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T22:57:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1844798879.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
